Stack Container¶

The Stack container module holds a list of elements. Elements are added to the top of the stack, and retrieved from the top of the stack (FIFO).

List of Functions¶

  • Stack()
  • clear()
  • isEmpty()
  • peek()
  • pop()
  • push(value)
class containers.stack.Stack(elements=None)¶

Bases: object

Instantiate a new Stack.

Parameters:elements (list) – list of elements (optional)

Examples

>>> s1 = Stack()
>>> s2 = Stack([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])
>>> print(s1)
[]
>>> print(s2)
[5, 4, 3, 2, 1]
clear()¶

Clear all elements from the stack.

Examples

>>> s1 = Stack([1, 2, 3])
>>> s1.clear()
>>> print(s1)
[]
isEmpty()¶

Checks if stack is empty.

Examples

>>> s1 = Stack([1, 2, 3])
>>> v1 = s1.isEmpty()
>>> print(v1)
False
>>> s2 = Stack()
>>> v2 = s2.isEmpty()
>>> print(v2)
True
Returns:True or False
Return type:bool
peek()¶
Preview first element in stack.
Only returns None if stack is empty.

Examples

>>> s1 = Stack([1, 2, 3])
>>> v1 = s1.peek()
>>> print(v1)
3
>>> s2 = Stack()
>>> v2 = s2.peek()
>>> print(v2)
None
Returns:first element in stack or None
Return type:mixed
pop()¶
Pop first element off stack and return.
Returns None if stack is empty.

Examples

>>> s1 = Stack([1, 2, 3])
>>> v1 = s1.pop()
>>> print(v1)
3
>>> print(s1)
[2, 1]
Returns:first element in stack or None
Return type:mixed
push(value)¶

Pushes a new value to front of stack.

Parameters:value (mixed) – new element

Examples

>>> s1 = Stack([1, 2, 3])
>>> s1.push(4)
>>> print(s1)
[4, 3, 2, 1]
